cyclone.name: LAURA
cyclone.current_location: about 50 mi N of the western tip of Cuba
cyclone.trajectory: accelerating northwest across the central Gulf today, then turning northwest to north-northwest toward the upper Texas and southwest Louisiana coast Wednesday night
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: near the Texas–Louisiana border, roughly between Port Arthur TX and Lake Charles LA

weather_observation.watch_coast: Port Bolivar TX to west of Morgan City LA (Hurricane Watch); San Luis Pass TX to Ocean Springs MS (Storm Surge Watch)
weather_observation.warning_coast: None issued for Texas as of this advisory
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Upper Texas coast (including Galveston Bay) and southwest Louisiana coast
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm-force winds (35–45 kt) possible Wednesday afternoon, with a 14% chance of sustained 50-kt winds and isolated hurricane-force gusts if the center tracks closer.
weather_observation.storm_surge: Galveston Bay 2–4 ft; nearby Bolivar Peninsula 4–6 ft possible if surge peaks at high tide.
weather_observation.rainfall: 4–6 inches of rain possible Wednesday night–Thursday with locally higher totals, producing flash-flood potential in the Houston metro and along the ship channel.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Isolated tornadoes in outer rainbands Wednesday night; dangerous rip currents and large breaking waves along the entrance channel ahead of landfall.
